articles.title: West Virginia’s Ski Season Kicks Off On Thursday, December 4th
articles.description: Three West Virginia ski resorts are set to open up for the 2025/2026 winter season this week, the first of which opens Thursday.
articles.content: Three West Virginia ski resorts are set to open up for the 2025/2026 winter season this week, the first of which opens tomorrow, Thursday, December 4th. View this post on Instagram A post shared by Timberline Mountain (@timberlinemountain) Timberline Mountain in Davis is opening first, with snowmaking teams working hard to get the area’s most popular terrain ready for the season. It’s not yet clear exactly what terrain will be open tomorrow, though more and more terrain will gradually open following the first day of the season. Between December 4th and December 11th, “Bonus Day” lift tickets will cost just $69 and rentals will cost just $29 per day. Snowshoe Mountain in Snowshoe will open up on Friday, December 5th, with the mountain operations team similarly working very hard to take advantage of cold weather for snowmaking. articles.title: Like Willy Wonka’s Everlasting Gobstopper, Mount Bohemia’s $99 Season Pass Is Simply Unbelievable
articles.description: Michigan's Mount Bohemia $99 season ski pass is simply incredible.
articles.content: Author: Stacy Pokrywka While almost the entire ski resort industry is moving toward big-box corporate entities and mega-passes, Mount Bohemia in Michigan’s Upper Peninsula is bucking the trend with its $99 season pass . Mount Bohemia is keeping skiing and snowboarding wild, with the most unique vibe I’ve ever experienced. Would a $99 season pass get you stoked for the season? Yeah, me too. But how stoked would you be if I told you the $99 pass also comes with reciprocal days at hills and mountains all over the U.S. and Canada, full access to a legit outdoor Nordic Spa, and gnarly tree skiing with “no beginners allowed” ? Sounds amazing, right? It is. If you haven’t heard about Mount Bohemia, let me give you the lowdown on this ridiculously fun mountain and all the season pass perks. articles.title: Wishing Klaus Obermeyer A Happy 106th Birthday!
articles.description: Huge shoutout to Klaus Obermeyer who turned 106th today. Klaus was born in Germany in 1919 and witnessed the rise of Nazi fascism. He escaped Germany into Switzerland on skis. During the escape he was shot and fell off a cliff breaking his leg. Klaus managed to get out of the mountains alive and was […]
articles.content: Huge shoutout to Klaus Obermeyer who turned 106th today. Klaus was born in Germany in 1919 and witnessed the rise of Nazi fascism. He escaped Germany into Switzerland on skis. During the escape he was shot and fell off a cliff breaking his leg. Klaus managed to get out of the mountains alive and was found by a sympathetic nurse who hid him in a Swiss hospital until the WW2 was over. Klaus then moved to Aspen in 1947 where he started Sport Obermeyer . During his first year as a ski instructor at Aspen, Klaus noticed all of the inadequacies of his students’ gear and headed to the drawing table. Klaus created nearly a dozen ski industry firsts, including quilted down parkas turtlenecks, dual construction ski boots, pre-shaped gloves, mirrored sunglasses, and high altitude sunscreen. Certified legend. We wish very happy 106th birthday! Categories: Skiing

articles.title: Survivalist Feels Honored To Come Face-To-Face With A Mountain Lion
articles.description: When wilderness skills instructor Callie Russell came face-to-face with a mountain lion in a tree, she explained her gratitude.
articles.content: There are an estimated 20,000 to 40,000 mountain lions still living in the United States, primarily living in the western half of the country. Human population growth, poaching, hunting, development, pollution, and habitat loss all threaten their numbers. Spotting one in the wild is a rare occurrence, and while they might seem intimidating, many people are honored to see a mountain lion in the wild. Wilderness skills instructor Callie Russell , who participate on Season 7 of the the show Alone , is one of those people. When she came face-to-face with a mountain lion in a tree, she explained how much gratitude she had for the moment. “ There was a time, long ago, when I was afraid of the large wild predators, mostly when I slept in wild places by myself, with no tent, or anything separating me from them, over the years, I have had several close encounters with mountain lions, bears, and wolves, and now I do not have any fear for them, just deep reverence and respect. articles.title: These Six North American Ski Resorts Are Having Great Starts To Their Seasons
articles.description: While many ski regions in the US & Canada struck out last month, these six ski resorts had a great November.
articles.content: This past November will mostly be remembered for its snowless scenes in mountainous locations across North America. Popular ski resorts in Colorado, Tahoe, and Utah had little snow, resulting in many jarring images and videos. However, it wasn’t all bad for North America’s ski industry. Snow arrived in Canada and parts of the Northeast early, allowing for some memorable starts to the season. Here are six ski resorts in North America that have great starts to their seasons. Banff Sunshine Village : If you’re looking to go on a ski vacation soon and have access to lots of terrain, Banff is the place to go. Banff Sunshine Village was the first to open for the season in Canada, thanks to lots of natural stuff. Currently, the ski resort already has 78 trails and 11 lifts open. So far this ski season, Sunshine Village has received 200 centimeters (6 feet 7 inches) of snow at its summit. articles.title: New Alberta Law Could Help Revive Famous Lost Ski Resort
articles.description: Perhaps the most famous lost ski resort in Canada could be on the comeback trail thanks to a new Alberta law.
articles.content: Alberta — After years in limbo, Fortress Mountain is shaping up for a comeback. The question is how long it may take. Rocky Mountain Outlook reported last month that the current owners of Fortress Mountain Resort are working on a plan for the revival of the ski resort. The work is still in the early phases, and more approvals will be needed before work can begin. These new efforts are thanks to the All-Season Resorts Act. Passed in 2024, this Alberta law helps make it easier to build or revive a ski resort, such as Fortress Mountain. This is part of Alberta’s plan to increase its tourism revenue from nearly CAD$14.5 billion in 2025 to CAD$25 billion by 2035. Andrew Boitchenko, the Tourism and Sport Minister of Alberta, said the following about the proposal and the All-Season Resorts Act: “The regulatory framework for all-season resorts is still being finalized and no land has been designated at this time. articles.title: Jackson Hole Mountain Resort Kicks Off 60th Anniversary Winter Season On Thursday
articles.description: Jackson Hole Mountain Resort is set to kick off their 60th anniversary winter season this Thursday, December 4th.
articles.content: Jackson Hole Mountain Resort is set to kick off their 60th anniversary winter season this Thursday, December 4th, after delaying their opening day late last month. Continuous snowmaking efforts, 65 inches of snowfall at the summit, and 34 inches of snowfall mid-mountain have allowed for coverage across a significant portion of the north side of the resort. Three lifts will be open for the first day of the season, including Teewinot, Après Vous, and the Sweetwater Gondola up to the Mid-Station. Beginner and intermediate terrain will be available, though early season conditions and hazards will exist. View this post on Instagram A post shared by Jackson Hole Mountain Resort (@jacksonhole) The resort is hoping to announce addition terrain and lift openings heading into the weekend of December 6th-7th, or sooner if the conditions cooperate.
